documentType: Bureau of Prisons internal memorandum and psychological reconstruction report
summary: This is a Bureau of Prisons psychological reconstruction report on the suicide of inmate Jeffrey Epstein on August 10, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York. The report details Epstein's background, legal history, mental health assessments, and the circumstances leading to his death, noting limitations in the investigation due to the FBI confiscating video evidence and the inability to conduct formal interviews. This document is part of an internal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) report reviewing the circumstances surrounding Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and death at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. It details numerous procedural failures, documentation inaccuracies, and policy violations related to Epstein's housing, suicide watch, observation, and institutional management leading up to his death on August 10, 2019.

connections.description: Described as Epstein's ex-girlfriend and alleged associate who assisted with his criminal activities.
Officer was responsible for observing and documenting Epstein's behavior while on suicide watch and wrote the initial incident report after finding him unresponsive.
Ms. attempted to correct Officer's error in the suicide watch log book by copying his entries, which created a misleading record.
Ms. conveyed the discovery of the suicide watch log book irregularities to Dr. via email, with a copy to the Warden.
Ms. emailed the lieutenant expressing concerns about Epstein's mental state on July 6, 2019; the lieutenant opened the email but did not follow required procedures.
Mr. escorted Epstein to place an unmonitored telephone call on August 9, 2019, and was told by Epstein he was calling his deceased mother.

events.title: Florida Guilty Plea
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein entered a non-prosecution agreement and pleaded guilty to one count of Solicitation of Prostitution and one count of Procuring a Person Under the Age of 18 for Prostitution in Florida.

events.title: Federal Indictment
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was formally charged with Sex Trafficking Conspiracy and Sex Trafficking in the Southern District of New York.

events.title: Arrest at Teterboro
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was arrested at Teterboro Airport in New Jersey upon his return from Paris, France, and transported to MCC New York.

events.title: Bail Denied
events.description: Judge Richard M. Berman denied Jeffrey Epstein's request for bail and pretrial release, remanding him to custody.

events.title: First Suicide Incident
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell with a piece of orange cloth around his neck, resulting in him being placed on suicide watch. He claimed his cellmate may have tried to kill him.

events.title: Documents Unsealed
events.description: Approximately 2,000 pages of court documents were unsealed, containing graphic allegations against Epstein and naming other high-profile figures.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at MCC New York at approximately 6:33 a.m. and was pronounced dead at a hospital at 7:36 a.m. The report concludes his death was a suicide.

events.title: Epstein arrives at MCC New York
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein arrives at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York. A facility assistant observes him as 'distraught, sad and a little confused' and emails psychologists and a lieutenant expressing concern about potential suicidal thoughts.

events.title: Inaccurate Psychology Intake Screening
events.description: Dr. [Redacted] completes a Psychology Services Intake Screening for Epstein with multiple errors: incorrectly checking 'No Sexual Offense Convictions', misidentifying his race, and once referring to him as 'Mr. Brown'.

events.title: Epstein denied bail
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is denied bail, which the report notes was a 'significant disappointment' that likely challenged his ability to adapt to incarceration.

events.title: Epstein found unresponsive in cell
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is found unresponsive in his cell with abrasions on his neck and knee. Inconsistent documentation emerges regarding the object around his neck (a 'string' vs. 'piece of handmade orange cloth'). An incident report for 'Self-Mutilation' is written.

events.title: Epstein on Suicide Watch
events.description: Epstein is placed on suicide watch. During this time, he has extended attorney visits without the required 'direct, continuous observation' by BOP staff.

events.title: Extended Attorney Visits on Psychological Observation
events.description: While on Psychological Observation (not formal suicide watch), Epstein has attorney visits totaling over 60 hours across six days, again without continuous observation as required.

events.title: Inconclusive SIS Threat Assessment
events.description: A Special Investigative Services Threat Assessment is completed but is inconclusive as to whether Epstein's injuries on July 23 were from self-directed violence, a fight with his cellmate, or an assault by his cellmate.

events.title: Unmonitored Telephone Call
events.description: Epstein terminates a legal visit to place a telephone call. He is escorted to the SHU and, lacking his PIN, a Unit Manager dials a number with area code 347. Epstein claims he is calling his mother, who has been deceased since 2004.

events.title: Inaccurate SENTRY Cell Assignment
events.description: A SENTRY quarters roster shows three inmates, including Epstein, assigned to his double-occupancy SHU cell, indicating a systemic failure in inmate tracking software.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide on August 10, 2019, while in custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York.
The reconstruction was severely limited because the FBI confiscated the original video evidence and formal interviews were not conducted to avoid interfering with other DOJ investigations.
Epstein was found with a cloth around his neck on July 23, 2019, in an incident initially reported as a possible assault by his cellmate, but later treated as self-directed violence.
On the night of his death, Epstein was single-celled because his cellmate did not return from court, and staff failed to complete required 30-minute rounds at 3:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m.
The report notes that on August 9, 2019, the day before his death, approximately 2,000 pages of court documents containing graphic allegations were unsealed, potentially eroding his status.
There were significant inconsistencies in the documentation of the scene when Epstein was found unresponsive on July 23, 2019, including conflicting descriptions of the object around his neck.

Critical procedural failures occurred, including lack of direct observation during Epstein's suicide watch and extended attorney visits, failure to follow up on staff concerns about his mental state, and inaccurate inmate tracking in the SENTRY system.

Staff made numerous documentation errors: a psychologist incorrectly recorded Epstein's criminal history and race; a Drug Treatment Specialist improperly altered suicide watch logs; and various logs (attorney, observation, SHU records) were incomplete, inaccurate, or unsecured.
Epstein was allowed to make an unmonitored telephone call on August 9, 2019, to a number with area code 347, which he claimed was to his deceased mother.

The report concludes that a broad understanding of sex offender risk factors among MCC staff was lacking, and recommends supplemental training and a more focused management strategy for high-profile cases.
